(CNN)Five Americans who were monitored for three weeks at an Omaha, Nebraska, hospital after being exposed to Ebola in West Africa have been released, a Nebraska Medicine spokesman said in an email Wednesday. One of the five had a heart-related issue on Saturday and has been discharged but hasn't left the area, Taylor Wilson wrote. The others have already gone home. They were exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone in March, but none developed the deadly virus. They are clinicians for Partners in Health, a Boston-based aid group. They all had contact with a colleague who was diagnosed with the disease and is being treated at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland. As of Monday, that health care worker is in fair condition. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta has said the last of 17 patients who were being monitored are expected to be released by Thursday. More than 10,000 people have died in a West African epidemic of Ebola that dates to December 2013,

The new research suggests that Anne and Margot Frank died at least a month earlier than previously thought, contradicting the date of death determined by Dutch authorities. Norfolk, Virginia (CNN)The second mate of the Houston Express probably couldn't believe what he was seeing. Hundreds of miles from land there was a small boat nearby. At first it looked abandoned. It was in bad shape, listing to one side. The crew of the 1,000-foot long container ship thought it was a yacht that had wrecked. Incredibly, as they got closer, they saw there was a man on it, signaling for help. "He was moving, walking around, waving to us and in surprisingly good condition," Capt. Thomas Grenz told CNN by phone Friday. That man, Louis Jordan, 37, had an amazing story. He'd been drifting on the 35-foot Pearson sailboat for more than two months since leaving Conway, South Carolina, to fish in the ocean. Just a few days into his trip, a storm capsized his boat and broke his mast. One of his shoulders was broken, too, so he couldn't fix the boat right away.

The California drought has significant impacts on the rest of the nation, affecting food prices, livestock, and wine production. The drought has led to a decrease in the snowpack in the Sierra Nevada, causing ski resorts to shut down early and prompting the construction of alternative attractions. The drought has also led to a mandatory request for water and laundry services at hotels, and decorative fountains in homes have been turned off. Despite these challenges, the drought has led to a record high California wine grape harvest in 2014, with excellent quality. 🎓

Iran's Islamic Revolution in 1979 led to a ban on women attending most sports events involving men. However, a top Iranian sports official announced plans to lift the ban for some events, including indoor sports, in the next year. The ban was reinstated in 2005 after the more hard-line Mahmoud Ahmadinejad came to power. FIFA President Sepp Blatter called on Iran to end the ban, citing it as intolerable. The ban came under the spotlight at the Asian Cup in Australia earlier this year, when thousands of female Iranian fans watched their soccer team without restriction. Iranian officials have denied that Ghoncheh Ghavami was arrested for attending the volleyball match, saying she was taken into custody for "anti-Iran activities." The news agency Reuters reported that she was recently pardoned by the Court of Appeal. 🎓

Online activity, including blogs, YouTube channels, and social media platforms, has become the alternative to traditional mainstream media in authoritarian countries. The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is a particle accelerator that generates up to 600 million particles per second, with a beam circulating for 10 hours, traveling more than 6 billion miles. The LHC aims to recreate the conditions that existed moments after the "Big Bang" to uncover how the universe evolved. The LHC could also question the idea that the universe is only made of matter, despite the theory that antimatter must have been produced in the same amounts at the time of the Big Bang. The LHC costs approximately three billion euros and complies with Swiss and French laws and a European Council Directive. 🎓

A nearly five-minute total lunar eclipse is visible in western North America this morning. The moon will turn dark and may appear red due to Earth's atmosphere filtering out most of the blue light. Lunar eclipses typically happen at least twice a year, but this series of four in a row is known as a "tetrad." The first was on April 15, 2014, and the next is on September 28. 🕑

The terrorist group Al-Shabaab has claimed an attack on Garissa University College in eastern Kenya, resulting in many deaths and hostages. Easter is a Christian holiday that celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ. It is celebrated on a different date each year, determined by the lunar calendar. The Easter Bunny and colorful eggs are popular Easter traditions that originated in Germany and have become a part of the holiday. The date of Easter is determined by the first full moon after the vernal equinox, which is the day when the sun is directly above the equator. The Easter Bunny and eggs are associated with pagan traditions and are believed to have originated in Germany. Coloring Easter eggs with Kool-Aid is a fun and easy way to celebrate the holiday. 🎂

Andrew Harrison, a black basketball player at the University of Kentucky, apologized for using offensive language towards a white player, Frank Kaminsky, after a loss to Wisconsin. Kaminsky said he was over it and wished Harrison well in the championship game. 🎓

The FBI confirmed that Marwan, a Malaysian bomb maker and member of Jemaah Islamiyah's central command, was killed in a disastrous raid in the Philippines in January. Marwan was previously falsely reported dead after a raid in 2012. The Philippines has been fighting an insurgency in the predominantly Muslim south for years, and last year signed a peace agreement with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). However, a surprise raid in pursuit of Marwan at Mamapasono, in the southern province of Maguindanao, went disastrously awry, resulting in the deaths of 44 members of the police's elite Special Action Force (SAF) unit. The IPAC report argues that the "single-minded focus" of authorities on killing Marwan has threatened the peace agreement with the MILF, which is yet to cross the final hurdle of being passed into law by the Philippines Congress. 🎓user

The FBI confirmed that Marwan, a Malaysian bomb maker and member of Jemaah Islamiyah's central command, was killed in a disastrous raid in the Philippines in January. Marwan was previously falsely reported dead after a raid in 2012.

The Delaware family fell ill after staying at a luxury villa in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where a harmful pesticide was detected. The EPA is investigating whether the family was exposed to the pesticide during a fumigation at the resort on March 18. The use of methyl bromide is restricted in the United States due to its acute toxicity and is not allowed indoors. Sea Glass Vacations, which rents the villa, did not treat the unit for pests, but licensed Terminix for pest control services. The U.S. Department of Justice has initiated a criminal investigation into the matter. 🎓

Comedian Chris Rock has shared three traffic stops in seven weeks, sparking debate over racial disparities in police treatment. He advises African-Americans to avoid racial profiling by adapting their behavior, such as wearing pants and bringing a white friend along for the ride. 🎓

A chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, experienced an explosion and fire after an oil leak, injuring six people. The plant produces paraxylene, a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The fire is now under control, and more than 600 firefighters were sent to battle it. Demonstrations against PX plant construction have occasionally turned violent in several cities in recent years. 🎓

The United States Department of Justice has indicted FedEx for conspiring to transport prescription pharmaceuticals dispensed with illegal prescriptions, violating the Controlled Substances Act, and money laundering. FedEx argues that it is a common carrier and should not be held liable for possessing contraband. The government's underlying intentions are to attack the supply line of the illegal drug market by attacking the actual supply chain.

Mark Wahlberg will star in a film about the Boston Marathon bombing and the manhunt that followed, titled "Patriots' Day." The film will be told from Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis' point of view and will feature material researched and shot by CBS Films' corporate sibling, "60 Minutes." Wahlberg is also a producer of the film. 🎓
On Thursday's "The Price Is Right," model Manuela Arbelaez accidentally revealed the correct answer to a guessing game, resulting in a new Hyundai Sonata being given to her. 🎓

Carlos Colina, 32, was charged with assault and battery causing serious bodily injury and improper disposal of a body after authorities discovered human remains in a duffel bag in Cambridge, Massachusetts. 🎓
"Arrested Development" executive producer Brian Grazer announced that the show will return for a fifth season of 17 episodes. 🎓

"Mad Men" is set in the 1960s, a decade marked by social and cultural upheaval. The show's final season will likely focus on the events of 1969, including the moon landing, the Woodstock festival, and the Vietnam War. The characters will continue to grapple with the disintegration of the old order and the rise of new ideas. Don Draper's departure is a possibility, as he suffers from heart attacks and struggles with alcoholism. Peggy Olson's agency merger and marriage are also likely plot points. The show's final season will likely be a reflection of the decade's tumultuous events and the characters' struggles to adapt to changing times. 🎗

Nina Dobrev, star of "Vampire Diaries," announced her departure from the CW show at the end of this season. Many fans were upset that her departure could affect the relationship between Elena Gilbert and Damon Salvatore, who are known as "Delena." Producer Julie Plec supported Dobrev's decision and expressed excitement for the future of the show. Fans were divided, with some feeling angry and sad, while others were supportive. 🎓

Police arrested four employees of a popular Indian ethnic-wear chain after a minister spotted a security camera overlooking the changing room of one of its stores. The four employees have been charged with voyeurism and breach of privacy, and could face up to three years in jail if convicted. 🎓

Nine British citizens were arrested in Turkey on Wednesday, suspected of trying to illegally cross into Syria. The group included four children, with the oldest being 10 or 11, and the youngest born in 2013. The nine were arrested at the Turkey-Syria border, and all had British passports. The British Foreign Office is seeking information about the incident from Turkish authorities. 🎓

A Russian nuclear submarine undergoing repairs at the Zvyozdochka shipyard in northwestern Russia caught fire, according to ITAR-Tass. The submarine is in a dry dock and has no ammunition on board. The fire began as welding work was being done on the submarine, and insulation caught on fire. No nuclear fuel or armaments are present on the submarine, and no one has been injured. 🕑

Kayahan, a beloved Turkish singer and songwriter, died of cancer at the age of 66. He was known for his love songs and had a successful career, releasing nearly 20 albums. His final album was released in 2007. 🕑

Former Chinese security czar Zhou Yongkang was charged with accepting bribes, abuse of power, and leaking state secrets. He was one of nine men who effectively ruled China, and his alleged actions caused heavy losses to public assets and greatly harmed national interests. Zhou has not been seen in public since he attended an anniversary event at his alma mater in October 2013. He was expelled from the Communist Party and arrested last December. State media have painted an intricate web of officials, cronies, and tycoons orbiting around Zhou before his downfall. Zhou and his family members were said to have accumulated enormous wealth, in a blatant exchange between money and power. He was also found to have affairs with multiple women and allegedly traded power for sex. Zhou's downfall is viewed as a watershed moment in the secretive world of Chinese politics, now ruled by President Xi Jinping, who has been spearheading a massive anti-corruption campaign. 🎓

The New Testament mentions money 119 times, with Jesus emphasizing the importance of helping the poor. Jesus and his disciples lived a simple life, relying on begging and hospitality to survive. Women like Mary Magdalene and Joanna provided financial support for Jesus, and wealthy men like Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus also contributed to his ministry. The church's relationship to money became more complicated as the needs grew, and the Gospels reveal that Jesus' followers grew exponentially after his resurrection. 🎓

A group of armed assailants attacked the attorney general's office in Balkh province, northern Afghanistan, killing three people and wounding five others. Afghan security forces are engaged in an exchange of fire with the assailants, while trying to avoid civilian casualties. 🎓

Rand Paul, a Kentucky State Senator, is running for president of the United States. He claims to be a minority outreach candidate, but his policies do not align with the issues facing minority communities. Paul has a history of questioning landmark voting rights and civil rights legislation, and has been criticized for his views on discrimination and the Voting Rights Act. He has also been accused of lacking cultural competency in his speeches at historically black colleges and universities. The American people deserve a leader who will not disrespect their intelligence, pander to them, or work to dismantle progress made over the last five decades. 🕑

A French-language global television network, TV5Monde, experienced a cyberattack that crippled its broadcasts and social media accounts. The network regained control of one of its 11 channels and its Facebook page by late morning, but some pages on its website were still under maintenance. The outage began around 8:45 p.m. Paris time on Wednesday. 🎓

Jennifer Stewart's pet cat, Felix, went missing after Etihad Airways lost his luggage during a flight from Abu Dhabi to New York City. The airline is investigating the incident and has hired third-party specialists to help locate the missing cat. Stewart and her husband booked the cat's flight as part of their job relocation to the United States. 🎓

Tuesday's top stories include the closing of two high-profile trials in Massachusetts, the announcement of Sen. Rand Paul's presidential bid, and the first runoff for a citywide office in Chicago. The trials involve Aaron Hernandez and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, while the presidential race is between Rand Paul and Sen. Ted Cruz. The Chicago runoff pits Mayor Rahm Emanuel against Jesus "Chuy" Garcia, and the Ferguson election will bring change to the predominantly black population. 🎓
A fire broke out at the General Electric Appliance Park in Louisville, Kentucky, on Friday morning. The cause of the fire is unknown, but firefighters are working to contain the damage. 🎓

Ted Cruz, a presidential candidate from Texas, visited Iowa to connect with voters on a religious level. He was one of the loudest defenders of the religious freedom law in Indiana, which came under fire last week for what critics called paving a path to discrimination against gays and lesbians. Cruz's first television ads are appearing this weekend during programs on Fox News and NBC that are pegged to Easter Sunday. Cruz's campaign believes that if it can tap into the group of evangelicals who've been staying home and get the demographic as a whole to overperform, then that could mean the difference of millions more at the polls. Russell Moore, president of the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, said he expects to see record turnout among evangelicals in 2016 no matter who the nominee is or what that person says. Cruz's campaign believes that if it can tap into the group of evangelicals who've been staying home and get the demographic as a whole to overperform, then that could mean the difference of millions more at the polls. Russell Moore, president of the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, said he expects to see record turnout among evangelicals in 2016 no matter who the nominee

The terrorist attack at Garissa University College in Kenya killed 142 students, three security officers, and two university security personnel. Kenyan authorities have not released a list of the victims. The attack was the nation's deadliest since the bombing of the U.S. Embassy in 1998. Kenyan churches mourned the dead during Easter services, and armed guards protected the congregations. The Interior Ministry has identified one of the attackers killed by security forces as the son of a government official. The Islamist extremist group is based in Somalia and has also killed Muslims in recent attacks. 🎓

The California Public Utilities Commission has ordered Pacific Gas & Electric Co. to pay a record $1.6 billion penalty for unsafe operation of its gas transmission system, including the pipeline rupture that killed eight people in San Bruno in 2010. Most of the penalty will go toward improving pipeline safety, while $50 million will go toward other remedies. PG&E's CEO said the company is working to become the safest energy company in the United States and has already replaced more than 800 miles of pipe and implemented safety recommendations. The previous record penalty was a $146 million penalty against Southern California Edison Company in 2008. 🎓

The Boston Marathon bombing trial resulted in Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's conviction on all 30 charges, including 17 capital charges for which he is eligible for the death penalty. The penalty phase will begin, where jurors will weigh aggravating and mitigating factors to decide whether Tsarnaev should be executed. 🎓
Four workers died in a massive oil rig fire in Mexico, with 45 workers injured. The fire was extinguished by Wednesday night, and there was no oil spill. 🎓
Indian police are using pepper-spraying drones to control unruly crowds, with concerns raised about the suppression of freedom of speech and the need for regulation. 🎓

The Secret Service is facing a new scandal after a female employee accused a supervisor, Xavier Morales, of assault. Morales was placed on administrative leave and his security clearance was suspended. This is the latest scandal for the agency, which has faced scrutiny over the past several months. 🎓

Investigators have collected all main evidence from the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash site in the Alps. The flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder were found, and 150 DNA profiles were isolated from the crash site. 470 personnel effects were found, including 40 cell phones in bad condition. The BEA found that Lubitz intentionally used controls to speed up the plane's descent. Lubitz had a history of depression and concealed medical leave notes from his employer. 🎓

April 8, 2015, was significant for "Lost" fans, but it was also "Rex Manning Day" in the 1995 film "Empire Records." Other notable dates in film history include April 14 for "Titanic," October 3 for "Miss Congeniality," and October 21, 2015, for "Back to the Future Part II." 🎓
Twisted Sister will tour in 2016 to celebrate its 40th anniversary, with a new drummer, Mike Portnoy, replacing A.J. Pero, who died in March. The tour will be titled "Forty and F*ck It." 🎓

Grace of Monaco, starring Nicole Kidman, is heading to Lifetime after a poor international reception. The film, directed by Olivier Dahan, focuses on Grace Kelly's period in the early '60s and was originally scheduled for release in late 2013. However, TWC pulled it out of awards contention and shifted its release to March 14, 2014, leading to a dispute between Dahan and Harvey Weinstein. The film was then scheduled for a U.S. release in May, but TWC did not slot it into its fall 2015 release schedule.

A massive tornado devastated parts of Illinois, killing one person and causing widespread damage. The tornado, which was the largest seen in the area in 40 years, passed through Rochelle and Kirkland, leaving behind a trail of destruction. The tornado also touched down in Iowa and Missouri, causing severe damage in those areas as well. Despite the devastation, no one was killed or seriously injured in the Midwest. The National Weather Service warned of a "particularly dangerous situation" and urged people to be on alert for severe weather.

The video shows a white North Charleston police officer, Michael Slager, shooting an unarmed black man, Walter Scott, eight times as he runs away. Slager has been fired and charged with murder. The video contradicts Slager's initial statement that he used a Taser on Scott, who tried to take the weapon. The video also shows a dark object falling behind Scott and hitting the ground, which is unclear whether it was the Taser. The video shows Slager handcuffing Scott after the shooting. The North Charleston Police Department is not providing additional information, citing an ongoing investigation. 🕑

Kanye West settled a lawsuit with a paparazzi photographer, Daniel Ramos, who had accused him of assaulting him and trying to wrestle his camera from him in July 2013 at Los Angeles International Airport. West pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor count of battery and was sentenced to two years' probation, anger management sessions, and community service. Ramos and his lawyer, Gloria Allred, sought general and punitive damages, but the case was settled to the satisfaction of the parties. 🎓

"American Pie" is a 1971 song by Don McLean, which became a cultural anthem for the generation lost in space. The song's lyrics and melody frame a cosmic dream, and it has been performed thousands of times, with the encore number never losing its transfixing allure. The song is a talisman that keeps bringing joy to listeners everywhere, and it is eternal. Tuesday, Christie's sold the 16-page handwritten manuscript of the song's lyrics for $1.2 million to an unnamed buyer.

Mary Kay Letourneau Fualaau, a married teacher and mother of four, had an affair with her 13-year-old student, Vili Fualaau. She gave birth to his child and served over seven years in prison for their sexual relationship. After her release, she and her husband, Vili Fualaau, celebrated their 10th wedding anniversary on May 20. In an exclusive interview with Barbara Walters, Mary Kay Letourneau Fualaau discussed what makes their marriage work despite their age difference, her plans to teach again, and her intentions to have her status as a registered sex offender lifted. Vili Fualaau discussed his battles with alcoholism, depression, and why he believes the system failed him while he was still a minor. Letourneau Fualaau is now 53, and her husband is 31. 🎓

The manuscript of Don McLean's "American Pie" sold for $1.2 million at an auction, making it the third highest auction price for an American literary manuscript. McLean said he wanted to get the best deal for his children and wife, and that he was going to be 70 years old. The song has been dissected and argued about for years, with various interpretations of its symbols. The manuscript includes lines that didn't make the final version and extensive notes, which should be revealing. The record for a popular music manuscript is held by Bob Dylan's "Like a Rolling Stone," which sold for $2 million in June. 🕑

Rinko Kikuchi was Oscar-nominated for her performance in the film "Babel." 🎓

HBO's documentary "Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief" is critical of the Church of Scientology, which has close ties to Hollywood. Actor John Travolta, a high-profile member of the church, has not seen the documentary and believes it is based on disgruntled experiences with the organization. Travolta credits Scientology with helping him survive the death of his son and calls it "brilliant." 🎓
